title: Fabrication of all-solid-state lithium battery with lithium metal anode using Al2O3-added Li7La3Zr2O12 solid electrolyte
A Lithium/Air Secondary Battery with a Water-Stable Lithium Anode and an Alkaline Aqueous Electrolyte
Polymerized ionic liquids with guanidinium cations as host for gel polymer electrolytes in lithium metal batteries
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Polymerized ionic liquids (PILs) having guanidinium cations with different counter‐anions, such as PF<jats:sub>6</jats:sub><jats:sup>−</jats:sup> and N(CF<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub><jats:sup>−</jats:sup> (TFSI<jats:sup>−</jats:sup>), were synthesized by copolymerization of a guanidinium ionic liquid monomer with methyl acrylate followed by an anion exchange reaction. Furthermore, incorporating a guanidinium ionic liquid, LiTFSI salt and nano‐size SiO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, a quaternary gel polymer electrolyte based on one of the PILs as the polymer host was prepared. The quaternary gel polymer electrolyte was chemically stable even at a higher temperature of 80 °C in contact with the lithium anode. In particular, the electrolyte exhibited high lithium ion conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window and good lithium stripping/plating performance. Li/LiFePO<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> batteries with the quaternary gel polymer electrolyte at 80 °C had capacities of 140 and 130 mA h g<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> respectively at 0.1 and 0.2 C current rates. Copyright © 2011 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

title: Ionic Liquid‐Based Membranes as Electrolytes for Advanced Lithium Polymer Batteries
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Gel‐type polymer electrolytes are formed by immobilizing a solution of lithium <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ethylpyrrolidinium <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Py<jats:sub>24</jats:sub>TFSI) ionic liquid (IL) with added mixtures of organic solvents, such as ethylene, propylene and dimethyl carbonates (EC, PC, and DMC, respectively), into a poly(vinylidenefluoride‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐hexafluoropropylene) (PVdF‐HFP) matrix, and their properties investigated. The addition of the organic solvent mixtures results in an improvement of the ionic conductivity and in the stabilization of the interface with the lithium electrode. Conductivity values in the range of 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup>–10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> S cm<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> are obtained in a wide temperature range. These unique properties allow the effective use of these membranes as electrolytes for the development of advanced polymer batteries based on a lithium metal anode and an olivine‐type lithium iron phosphate cathode.</jats:p>
